GLOSSARY 
 
agrarian reform  –  The  Comprehensive  Agrarian  Reform  Law  passed  in  1988 
beneficiary  designates  agrarian  reform  beneficiaries  (ARBs)  of  the 
Comprehensive  Agrarian  Reform  Program  (CARP)  as  the 
beneficiaries  of  land  distribution  under  CARP.  They  include 
agricultural  lessees  and  share  tenants;  regular  farm  workers; 
seasonal  farm  workers;  other  farm  workers;  actual  tillers  or 
occupants  of  public  lands;  collectives  or  cooperatives  of  the 
above beneficiaries; and others directly working on the lands that 
are under acquisition by the Government under CARP.

agrarian reform  –  A barangay or a cluster of barangays in which a critical mass of 
community   the population consists of ARBs. Further, to be designated as an 
agrarian reform community (ARC) by the Department of Agrarian 
Reform (DAR), the barangay or cluster of barangays in question 
is required to fulfill certain criteria. These include, among others, 
that (i) at least 50% of the population should consist of ARB 
households; (ii) cooperatives of the ARBs should have achieved a 
level of maturity in management, which is measured by DAR‘s 
assessment  of  the  level  of  development  of  ARCs,  (iii)  the 
community exhibits a willingness to adopt improved production 
and management practices; and (iv) at least 75% of the CARP 
scope for LAD is completed.  
 
The ARC concept emerged in 1993. It is central to DAR’s attempt 
to showcase that agrarian reform works to empower people and 
bring about sustainable agro-industrial development. This is to be 
done  through  a  holistic  implementation  of  land  reform 
accompanied  by  other  support  services  that  can  bring  about 
sustained improvements in the quality of lives of ARBs. The ARC 
concept also implies geographic convergence of all government 
and nongovernment agencies’ support services for maximizing 
efficiency and impacts of rural development efforts. 
 
ARC cluster  –  The term means an area consisting of 2 or more ARCs including 
the non–ARC barangays in the designated area and/or cluster. 
The term that has been variously adopted by DAR since 2006 as 
a concept that allows inclusion of non-ARB populations within and 
outside ARCs, as well as ARBs living in non-ARC barangays in 
the vicinity of designated ARCs within DAR’s programs and plans. 
The  ARC  cluster  approach  is  thus  expected  to  help  the 
Government  to  reach  larger  populations  than  those  of  the 
selected ARCs alone, to increase marketable surplus production, 
apply  the  agribusiness  concept  to  large  areas  of  agricultural 
lands, and achieve economies of scale. 
 
ARC connectivity  –  This term implies establishment of physical and other types of 
connectivity between ARCs and non-ARC areas covered under 
the  ARC  cluster  concept.  Through  improved  connectivity, 
economies  of  scale  may  be  achieved  in  terms  of  volumes  of 
produce  being  transported  to  markets;  increases  in  commuter 
traffic;  and  greater  efficiencies  in  markets,  investments,  and 
services. 
 
barangay  –  Tagalog  term  for  the  smallest  local  government  unit  in  the 
Philippines;  it  represents  a  village.  Municipalities  or  cities  are 
composed  of  barangays.    In  cities,  congressional  districts  are 
composed of clusters of barangays.  In provinces, congressional 
districts are composed of a cluster of municipalities.

community– –  Treats poor people and their institutions as assets and partners in 
driven  the search for sustainable solutions to development challenges. 
development  Community–driven  development  ––  broadly  defined  —  is  an 
approach  that  gives  control  over  planning  decisions  and 
investment  resources  to  community  groups  and  local 
governments. It facilitates inclusion of the poor in the community. 
It can ensure the participation of the different segments of the 
community  in  monitoring  project  activities,  procurement,  and 
implementation, as well as encourages transparency. 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars

LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of the Philippines 
   
Classification  Targeting classification:  Targeted intervention (TI-G) 
Sector: Agriculture and natural resources 
Subsector: Agricultural production, agroprocessing, and agribusiness 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, inclusive social development 
Subthemes:  Promoting  economic  efficiency  and  enabling  markets, 
developing rural areas, indigenous peoples 
   
Environment  Category B  
Assessment 
   
Project  The Project will provide continued support to the implementation of the 
Description  Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program (CARP) of the Government. It 
will provide holistic support to CARP by facilitating the access of target 
communities to essential support services and markets, in approximately 
152 target agrarian reform communities (ARCs) and 11 ARC clusters in 19 
of the poorest provinces of southern Philippines. It will help facilitate their 
transformation  from  subsistence  producers  toward  agribusiness 
development. It will include both agrarian reform beneficiaries (ARBs) and 
other segments of the rural poor in ARCs and ARC clusters in target 
municipalities.  The  Project  will  adopt  community–driven  development 
strategies to reach out to large segments of the rural poor in the target 
areas to strengthen their social capital. It aims to (i) substantially expand 
the rural production base by assisting the rural poor in the target areas to 
break out of subsistence production, diversify their livelihood activities, and 
increase  their  marketable  surplus;  (ii)  raise  production  and  distribution 
efficiency  in  project  areas  to  improve  quality  and  competitiveness;  (iii) 
improve the position of small farmers vis-à-vis the larger markets; (iv) 
improve employment opportunities for landless households in the target 
areas; and (v) promote equitable distribution of production and productivity 
gains among all segments of the rural poor in the target areas.  
 
The  Project  will  use  a  community–driven  development  approach  in  all 
target  ARCs  and  ARC  clusters  to  strengthen  social  capital  formation, 
increase the effective participation of the rural poor in community planning 
and implementation, and facilitate the formation of socially homogenous 
groups for community-based financial services. It will support participatory 
ARC  planning,  strengthen  community  involvement  in  prioritization  of 
project  interventions,  implement  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB) 
safeguard  policies,  and  improve  local  governance  among  ARC 
organizations and local government agencies, among others. Commercial 
activities among rural communities will be supported through productivity 
improvements,  agri-enterprise  development,  market  promotion, 
strengthening  of  farmer  organizations,  security  of  land  tenure,  and 
sustainable rural financial services. Rural infrastructure development will 
be supported to enhance ARC connectivity and to develop agri-business 
areas.  Project  management  will  be  mainstreamed  at  all  levels  in 
accordance with the Government’s priorities.

ii   
 
   
Rationale  Most  of  the  rural  poor  in  the  Philippines  are  landless  and  land-poor 
households inhabiting rural areas in southern Luzon, Mindanao, and the 
Visayas.  Their  lack  of  equitable  access  to  the  means  of  production, 
including  land,  capital,  irrigation,  technology,  information,  employment 
opportunities, and markets, leads to deep poverty and low living standards. 
The Government’s response to the widespread rural distress and unrest in 
the 1980s has been the CARP. CARP aims to acquire and redistribute all 
public  and  disposable  alienable  land  suited  to  agriculture,  as  well  as 
private agricultural lands above certain limits, irrespective of crops grown, 
to eligible ARBs. CARP includes support services to be provided to ARBs 
with a view to reducing their poverty and improving the sustainability of 
their  landholdings.  ADB  has  supported  the  implementation  of  CARP 
through its Agrarian Reform Communities Project (ARCP).  
 
Under the ARCP, ADB assisted the development coverage of 165 ARCs in 
35 provinces. The ARCP has been successful in achieving most of its 
targets with high rates of utilization of project financing. Targets for most of 
the components have been exceeded, especially for rural infrastructure, 
which  has  had  far-reaching  effects  on  the  access  of  target  ARCs  to 
processing facilities and bigger markets. Technology transfer for improving 
productivity and rural enterprise development has shown results in terms 
of sustainable increases in incomes for ARBs and other farmers. The 
ARCP has demonstrated the need for ensuring regular budgetary releases 
for project implementation. It has also brought home to both ADB and the 
Government  the  need  for  mainstreaming  project  management  and  for 
ensuring  high  standards  of  governance  and  fiduciary  responsibility  all 
around. 
 
Building  on  lessons  learned  from  the  ARCP,  as  well  as  the  lessons 
emerging from the impact assessments done for CARP (in 2003 and 2007) 
and other externally assisted projects, and in support of the priorities of the 
Government, the ARCP II will cover about 152 ARCs and 11 ARC clusters 
(target  ARCs  and  ARBs  and  other  farmers  in  adjacent  areas)  in  19 
provinces. It will provide targeted support in precisely those areas where it 
is  necessary  to  bring  about  fundamental  change  to  enable  the 
transformation  of  CARP  lands  into  agribusiness  lands.  It  will  thus 
contribute to pro-poor economic growth and lead to equitable sharing of 
the benefits of growth across regions and rural poor communities. 
   
Impact and  The long-term impact of the Project is to enable ARB households and 
Outcome  other segments of the rural poor in about 152 selected ARCs and 11 ARC 
clusters  in  19  provinces  to  reduce  their  poverty  and  have  sustained 
improvements in their incomes and quality of life. The Project is expected 
to bring about long-lasting improvements in the capabilities and well-being 
of poor and marginalized groups in the target communities.  
   
Project  The project investment cost is at $208.4 million, including taxes and duties 
Investment  of $18.2 million. The base cost is allocated among four components: $5.3 
Plan   million for community–driven development; $25.2 million for agriculture and

iii 
enterprise development; $135.2 million for rural infrastructure; and $9.6 
million for project management. Price and physical contingencies against 
anticipated negative impacts to the Project of inflation and extraordinary 
foreign exchange fluctuations within the project years are estimated at 
$21.7 million. Total financial charges for the loan from ADB ordinary capital 
resources amount to $10.4 million, and commitment charges $1.0 million.

  The Government has requested financial assistance of $100 million to help 
  implement the Project. About $70 million of such financing will come from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources, while about $30 million will come from 
the OPEC Fund for International Development (OFID) to be administered 
by ADB. The ADB ordinary capital resources portion of the loan will have a 
25-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  5  years,  an  interest  rate 
determined in accordance with the ADB LIBOR-based lending facility, plus 
a 0.20% spread; the commitment charge is calculated at a 0.15% rate on 
the un-disbursed loan balance; and such other terms and conditions set 
forth in the draft loan and project agreements. The OFID portion of the loan 
will have a 20-year maturity, including a 5-year grace period, a 1% service 
charge per annum, and 3% interest. 
   
Allocation and  The Government will allocate about $65.9 million of the ADB and OFID 
Relending  loan proceeds to municipal governments for priority rural infrastructure as 
Terms  a  mix  of  loan  and  grant;  this  will  complement  equity  contributions  of 
municipalities  and  beneficiaries.  The  proportion  of  loan  and  grant  and 
terms of the loan will be in accordance with the national government and 
local government unit (LGU) cost-sharing policy.

Implementation  The  Project  will  be  fully  mainstreamed  within  existing  government 
Arrangements  structures.  The  Department  of  Agrarian  Reform  (DAR)  will  be  the 
Executing Agency. A project executive committee will be set up, to be 
chaired by the DAR secretary. A national project coordinator at the DAR 
central office will liaise, coordinate, and report on project implementation. 
At regional and provincial levels, existing DAR offices will be implementing

iv   
 
agencies with full responsibility for project implementation and supervision. 
At  the  municipal  level,  LGUs  will  be  the  implementing  units,  in  close 
collaboration with the Municipal Agrarian reform Officers (MAROs). They 
will  set  up  local  project  offices  to  undertake  subproject  planning  and 
execution. The farmer organizations in the ARCs will be key partners in 
project  implementation.  In  addition,  the  CARP  partner  implementing 
agencies will enter into memorandums of agreement with DAR to provide 
technical support for implementation of the Project.  
   
Executing  Department of Agrarian Reform  
Agency 
   
Procurement  All goods and related services financed under the ADB loan, as well as the 
ADB-administered OFID loan, will be procured in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
   
Consulting  An estimated 1,230 person-months of consulting services, comprising 30 
Services  person-months of two international consultants and 1,200 person-months 
of  national  consulting  services  will  be  recruited  to  assist  the  national 
government  agencies,  municipal  and  provincial  LGUs,  and  local 
communities in project implementation. Consultants will be recruited in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time).  This excludes consultancy contracts for 
activity-specific services. 
   
Project  The Project will target more than 150,000 persons in about 44,000 ARB 
Benefits and  and  non-ARB  households  in  the  target  areas  in  19 provinces.  These 
Beneficiaries  include  large  numbers  of  the  poor  and  vulnerable  segments  of  the 
population. At least one third of the target population will be assisted to 
move out of poverty. The Project will contribute to increasing cropping 
intensity  and  crop  yields  through  irrigation  development.  Reduction  in 
transport  costs  resulting  from  better  access  to  infrastructure  will  be 
accompanied by better prices and greater value addition. Other benefits 
will include stronger and more representative farmer organizations in target 
ARCs and ARC clusters. The poor and vulnerable segments in target 
ARCs, particularly women, will be empowered through social inclusion and 
through the provision of potable water to target ARCs.  
 
The  poverty  impact  assessment  shows  that  landless  households  are 
expected to gain in terms of additional employment availability. The Project 
is expected to provide an additional 5 million person-days of unskilled labor 
and 2 million person-days of skilled labor in target ARCs and ARC clusters, 
benefiting  landless  and  other  rural  poor  households.  With  a  prevalent 
average rural poverty rate of 49%, and much higher rates in many project 
areas, the Project is expected to facilitate sustainable poverty reduction, 
with households achieving steady income increases above existing levels. 
Non-income poverty will be reduced by improving the access of the poor to 
various  kinds  of  capital  and  assets,  including  social,  physical,  natural, 
financial, human, and informational.

v 
Risks and  Risks  to  the  Project  arise  from  peace  and  security-related  concerns 
Assumptions  especially in the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (ARMM). Other 
risks pertain to corruption and weak governance. The high levels of equity 
contribution required of relatively poorer LGUs can become a potential 
problem for the Project in reaching out to extremely poor areas. Several 
LGUs  are  weak  with  regard  to  project  management—financial 
management  in  particular.  The  Project  is  expected  to  contribute  to 
reducing  conflict  and  improving  peace  and  security  through  social 
inclusion, and by working together with traditional community leaderships, 
particularly in ARMM. Improving livelihoods will further help to improve 
living standards and reduce conflict. Corruption will be reduced with close 
monitoring  by  the  Executing  Agency  of  financial  management  of  the 
Project by weak LGUs, especially in ARMM. Capacity development of such 
LGUs  to  improve  financial  management  will  also  be  provided  by  the 
Project. The 50% equity requirement of poorer LGUs will be dealt with by 
the provision of a refund to them of up to 20% of their equity upon their 
completion of agreed institutional reforms. Risks will also be managed by 
continued  attention  to  timely  resource  availability  and  capacity 
development of stakeholders at the national, LGU, and community levels. 
Regular  budget  releases  will  reduce  risks  of  delays  in  project 
implementation.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan and (ii) proposed administration of a loan provided by the OPEC Fund for International 
Development  (OFID),  both  to  the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  the  Agrarian  Reform 
Communities Project II.1  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Dynamics of Rural Poverty in the Philippines 
2.  Poverty in the Philippines is primarily rural. Rural society is characterized by a highly 
inequitable land ownership structure, lack of security of access to land and other means of 
production,  and  imperfect  factor  and  product  markets.  Levels  of  economic  inequality  are 
strikingly high. Inequality in land distribution in the Philippines is much higher than in other parts 
of Southeast Asia. Prior to the initiation of land reforms in the Philippines, almost 50% of the 
rural population was landless. Land ownership was concentrated in the hands of the rural elite. 
In 1971, almost 52% of land was owned by 15% of the population, consisting of the top 
landowning families.2 Almost one third of the 30 million hectares (ha) of land area in the country 
is deemed agricultural land. Ownership of most of these lands is monopolized by elite families, 
although  only  one  third  is  officially  reported  as  privately  owned  at  the  start  of  the 
Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program (CARP). The Gini coefficient of land ownership in 
1988 was 0.64.3 The lack of control over land has been one of the most persistent causes of 
poverty in the Philippines. By 2004, at least two out of every five Filipinos were poor.4 Despite 
some economic improvements in recent times, the Philippines still lags behind other countries in 
Asia with lower levels of gross domestic product (GDP) growth and investment per capita than 
for the region as a whole.5 Although the incidence of poverty in the Philippines has decreased in 
recent years, poverty still remains predominantly rural and fairly high, at the level of more than 
one third of the population (2005). About 49% of rural families rate themselves as poor.6 Poverty 
is highest among landless and marginal farm families. 
 
3.  The  2004  country  poverty  analysis  for  the  Philippines7  estimated  that  the  poverty 
headcount increased between 2000 and 2003 at a rate that was higher than between 1997 and 
2000, and that the sustained economic growth had not been pro-poor. Poverty is geographically

Technical Assistance to the Philippines for Agrarian Reform Communities II. (TA 4390). Manila. A multidisciplinary 
team of local and international specialists from the Southeast Asian Regional Center for Graduate Study and 
Research in Agriculture was engaged to undertake the preparatory work. 
2  Reyes, Celia M. 2002. Impact of Agrarian Reform on Poverty. Discussion Paper Series 2002-02. Manila: Philippine 
Institute of Development Studies.  
3  Putzel, J. 1992. A Captive Land: the Politics of Agrarian Reform in the Philippines. London: Catholic Institute for 
International Relations; Manila: Ateneo de Manila University Press; New York: Monthly Review Press.  
4  Borras, Saturnino M., Jr. 2006. Redistributive Land Reform in ‘Public’ (Forest) Lands? Lessons from the Philippines 
and their Implications for Land Reform Theory and Practice. Progress in Development Studies 6 (2). The Hague: 
Institute of Social Studies. 
5  During the period 1960–2003, per capita GDP grew at 1.4% per annum compared to an average rate of 5.4% for 
several other countries around the region. 
6  Social Weather Stations. 2005. Second Quarter 2005 Social Weather Survey. Manila. Fifty-seven percent of 
households rated themselves as poor and 12% reported hunger at least once in 3 months. Self-rated poverty levels 
were 55% in the National Capital Region, 53% in the rest of Luzon, 70% in the Visayas, and 52% in Mindanao. 
During field work done by the loan fact-finding mission, higher poverty levels (50–80%) were self-reported in 
agrarian  reform  communities  (ARCs)  in  Camarines  Sur,  Camarines  Norte,  Negros  Occidental,  Zamboanga 
Sibugay, and Maguindanao, among others. The poor reported incomes much lower than the poverty line. Landless 
laboring households were in much worse condition than agrarian reform beneficiaries (ARBs). 
7  ADB. 2005. Poverty in the Philippines: Income, Assets, and Access. Manila (Executive Summary).

2   
concentrated in southern Philippines, with about three quarters of the poor living in the rural 
areas in southern Luzon, large parts of Mindanao, and the Visayas. Interestingly, some of these 
areas are also those with high levels of land concentration and inequality. Rural landlessness is 
a good indicator for poverty and hunger. In the 1980s, landless farm workers, share tenants, 
and lessees made up about 5 million households that were eligible to be covered by land 
reform.  Even  today,  despite  the  implementation  of  CARP,  about  60%  of  its  intended 
beneficiaries remain landless. In addition, the landless workers who are not the intended CARP 
beneficiaries amount to about 13% of rural households.8 
  
4.  The  Gini  coefficient  of  agricultural  landholding  is  much  higher,  0.57  to  0.76  (in 
comparison  with  provinces  with  less  skewed  landholding)  for  the  provinces  of  Negros 
Occidental, Bukidnon and Davao del Sur and Davao del Norte in Mindanao which have highly 
skewed landholding patterns.9 While the lack of employment opportunities in the rural areas as 
well as population growth may well have contributed to the problem of poverty, there can be no 
doubt that institutional and policy issues related to access to land have a critical bearing on 
poverty reduction. Balisacan10 states that the situation in the Negros provinces of Visayas, 
Bukidnon, and Davao del Sur, Davao del Norte provinces of Mindanao, resembles that in Latin 
American countries. Aside from inequitable land holding patterns, the El Nino phenomenon has 
exposed the poor in particular to the impacts of natural disasters. Drought and floods brought 
about by El Nino in the first half of 2005 depressed agricultural growth, which was a meager 2%. 
Falling rice production contributed to slow agricultural growth and rice imports in 2005. A Social 
Weather Stations (SWS) survey in December 2005 on self-rated poverty and hunger indicated 
that many Filipinos are suffering from hunger—49% rated themselves as impoverished and 17% 
as hungry. The 2008 unprecedented rise in the international price of rice caused widespread 
problems in the Philippines, the world’s largest rice importer.  While the Government, its donor 
partners, and civil society acted to reduce the adverse impact on the poor, 59% of households 
rated themselves as poor according to the SWS survey in July 2008.11 
 
5.  The  Government  has  used  land  reform  as  a  major  policy  response  to  deal  with 
persistent  unrest  among  the  rural  poor  since  1935  and  rural  poverty  since  World  War  II. 
However, all these initiatives suffered from poor budgetary support, exclusion of the largest 
areas under plantations and export crop production. The greatest sources of inequality and 
concentration of land and power thus remained untouched. The programs excluded the landless 
agricultural workers who were among the poorest in the rural areas, often even poorer than 
tenants. 
 
6.  In 1988, as the first systematic attempt to end inequity in land ownership to promote 
rural  development  and  agrarian  reform,  President  Aquino  enacted  Republic  Act  6657,  the 
Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Law, which governs implementation of CARP. CARP was a 
break from all earlier attempts at land reform, and it has had far-reaching impacts on poverty 
reduction and rural economic growth. CARP was originally meant to be implemented in 10 
years,  ending  in  1998.  However,  because  of  landlord  resistance  and  budgetary  problems, 
CARP was not able to reach its targets of land acquisition and distribution. Therefore, it was 
extended until June 2008.12  
 
7.  In addition to land reform, strategies adopted by the Government to spur growth in the 
rural economy and bring about sustainable poverty reduction include President’s Arroyo’s 10-

3
point Agenda13 for Growth and the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan (MTPDP 2004–
2010).  The  Government  has  also  enacted  further  legislation,  including  the  Agriculture  and 
Fisheries Modernization Act (1997) to improve the competitiveness of agriculture, and the Local 
Government Code (1991) which seeks to devolve responsibility for frontline service delivery to 
local government units (LGUs). However, progress is constrained by (i) the low availability of 
public expenditures for infrastructure, transport linkages, and market development, especially in 
rural areas, (ii) the lack of efficient input distribution networks, (iii) the slow pace of actual 
devolution to LGUs, many of which lack effective capacity to undertake planning and delivery of 
services to their constituents, and (iv) the lack of effective planning and implementation of rural 
development. 
 
8.  Another factor that contributes to the weak performance of the agricultural economy vis-
à-vis poverty reduction relates to the lack of efficiency in allocation of public expenditures in 
agriculture. Historically the Philippine policy of food self-sufficiency has led to distortions in the 
allocation of public resources to rice and in the setting of tariff and nontariff barriers to imports.14 
Aside from the budgetary allocations for irrigation and production support, rice dominates public 
expenditures  for  farm  machinery,  post-harvest  equipment,  research  and  development,  and 
training programs. The distortions in public resource allocation created further inequalities as 
these targeted the better-endowed farmers with access to technical know-how of certified seed 
and irrigation. This has distorted incomes and raised rice prices for landless rural workers, small 
farmers operating marginal plots, non-irrigated rice farmers, fisherfolk, upland dwellers, and the 
urban poor. Dawe15 reported that the per capita incomes of landless rural workers were 30% 
lower than those of rice farmers.  High rice prices in 2008 hurt these sections along with the 
urban poor. 
 
9.  At present, several challenges face the Government in relation to rural poverty reduction 
and agricultural growth stimulation. The issues of inequity in land ownership, distortions in the 
factor and product markets, lack of allocative efficiencies in public resource management, high 
government  debt  burden,  and  rural  unemployment  and  underemployment  continue  to 
perpetuate a relatively weak performance in agriculture. The challenges relate to improving 
sustainability of rural livelihoods16 by developing holistic approaches to improve the investment 
into  equity,  increase  investments  in  rural  production,  and  generate  sufficient  employment 
opportunities to address the needs of the rural poor. The Government’s job creation target is 1.5 
million jobs per year. Achievements have been well below that.

adopted by the Department for International Development of the United Kingdom. It puts people at the center of 
development and views them as operating in a context of vulnerability. It provides a useful framework to 
understand the multidimensional nature of poverty, as defined by people themselves, as well as to analyze their 
relative access to various types of capital (financial, physical, human, natural, social, and information), and their 
relative ability to combine and utilize these assets as individuals and households to ensure access to adequate 
subsistence and well-being, including improvements in livelihoods without undermining the natural resource base.

2.  Strategies for Sustainable Livelihoods and Equitable Growth 
a.  History of Land Reforms in the Philippines 
10.  The Government enacted the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Law in 1988 in response 
to the historical inequity of land ownership and distribution of productive assets in agriculture, as 
well as the resultant rural unrest, which was widespread. Earlier attempts at land reform in the 
Philippines beginning in 1935 were seriously flawed. They were inadequate and were never 
intended to change the existing inequitable distribution of land and power. In 1972, the Marcos 
regime’s attempt to bring about land reform was compromised by the exclusion of all lands other 
than rice and corn lands, high land retention limits for absentee landowners, and a difficult 
process of securing land rights for the poor. It excluded from the purview of land reforms those 
plantations  and  export-oriented  farms  precisely  where  there  was  high  concentration  of 
ownership and operational holdings. The program’s exclusion of sugar and coconut haciendas, 
where most of the poorest workers were to be found, limited its impact at the very outset. The 
program also concentrated on tenancy regulation and resettlement. As a result, it was limited in 
its  scope  and  outreach  to  the  poor.  Only  3.2%  of  its  target  beneficiaries  were  issued 
emancipation patents. The program excluded landless agricultural workers numbering about  
3.4 million people, who were the poorest in the rural areas.17 
 
b.  Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program 
11.  In 1988, the circumstances were ripe for another attempt at agrarian reform in the 
country.  Widespread  problems  of  poverty  and  inequality  of  land  distribution  resulted  in 
continued rural unrest. In 1988, the Government brought forward the Comprehensive Agrarian 
Reform Law, which gave rise to CARP. CARP is fundamentally different from all earlier land 
reform programs in the following ways: (i) It includes within its purview all agricultural lands 
irrespective of the commodity being produced and the status of the tiller; (ii) It includes a 
comprehensive approach to agrarian reform including a program of support to agrarian reform 
beneficiaries (ARBs), especially the delivery of basic support services needed to transform the 
ARBs into efficient market-oriented producers; (iii) It reduces the retention limits for former 
landowners; (iv) It determines compensation to be paid to landowners based on just principles 
to be implemented by the Land Bank of the Philippines; and (v) It includes the principle that land 
awarded to the  beneficiaries is to be paid for by them to the Land Bank of the Philippines. 
 
12.  Under CARP, all landless farm workers were eligible to be considered as beneficiaries, 
provided they were landless and willing to farm the lands. The goal for CARP was to cover 
8.06 million ha under its land acquisition and distribution program. The Department of Agrarian 
Reform (DAR), which was set up by the Marcos regime under a separate piece of legislation as 
the  lead  agency  for  land  reform,18  was  deemed  as  the  agency  to  implement  CARP.  The 
Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) was placed in charge of the land 
acquisition and distribution for public alienable and disposable lands, as well as forested lands. 
The  implementation  of  CARP  was  to  be  completed  in  10  years  (1998);  however,  it  was 
implemented according to the availability of funds and capacity of implementing agencies. 
Delays occurred because of the considerable resistance by landowners, lack of coordination 
among  concerned  agencies  (including  DENR,19  DAR,  LGUs,  and  courts),  and  the  legal 
challenges  and  hurdles  posed  by  landlords.  With  the  implementation  of  the  program  still 
incomplete in 1998, CARP was extended by 10 years to June 2008. There are currently moves

the delivery of support services to ARBs already provided with land titles. 
 
13.  Important  aspects  of  the  program  remain  to  be  completed.  In  terms  of  overall 
accomplishment of the acquisition and distribution of all lands under CARP, by December 2006, 
DAR had distributed 6.7 million ha, or 82% of the overall target 8.06 million ha. Most of the 
lands included consist of settlement areas, landed estates, and other government-owned lands, 
which represent 45% of the entire scope for CARP. Land acquisition and distribution has been 
particularly slow for the 1.5 million ha of private agricultural lands under compulsory acquisition. 
In terms of public alienable and disposable lands, the accomplishment was 69% by December 
2006, due to delays in the conduct of surveys, reconstitution of land records, and resolution of 
land conflicts.20 Another important aspect relates to the areas already covered by CARP land 
acquisition and distribution. For a large part of such lands, DAR has issued collective certificates 
of land ownership award (CLOA), which means that work still remains to be done to demarcate 
and title individual title holders.  
 
14.  With  regard  to  the  provision  of  basic  support  services  to  the  ARBs,  inadequate 
budgetary  resources,  limited  technical  capacity,  and  weak  coordination  had  led  to  slow 
coverage by 1993. As a result, the Government, through DAR, in 1993 launched the agrarian 
reform communities (ARCs) approach to beneficiary development. The approach concentrates 
the provision of support services in selected areas and ensures convergence of services CARP 
impact assessments in 2003 and 2007 indicated that the ARC concept has been useful in 
achieving poverty reduction targets. ARCs were targeted in areas with high poverty incidence. 
ARCs did better reducing poverty than non-ARC areas. Income levels of ARBs in ARCs are 
higher than those of non-ARBs as well as other ARBs living outside ARC barangays. The ARC 
concept thus remains valid for poverty reduction. 
 
15.  By 2004, the Government had realized that while the ARC concept has helped it to 
target scarce resources to achieve maximum impacts, it is also a limiting concept when faced 
with the enormity of the task of poverty alleviation in the countryside and spurring sustainable 
growth.21 It excludes ARBs who do not live in barangays designated as ARCs. It also excludes 
non-ARB populations living in and outside of ARCs. DAR had established about 1,800 ARCs by 
December 2006. In line with the Government’s MTPDP, and the target of identifying 2 million ha 
of agribusiness lands, DAR is now pursuing a more inclusive approach to rural development. In 
a paradigmatic shift, it enlarged its client base from ARBs inside ARCs to include ARBs living in 
barangays not designated as ARCs, as well as non-ARBs living inside ARCs and in the vicinity 
of the target ARCs. As a result, enlarged populations of ARBs and non-ARBs are included in 
planning development strategies and interventions.22 This provides the basis for the ARC cluster 
approach23 to ARC connectivity. An ARC cluster is defined as an enlarged area covering a 
number of municipalities with a high density of ARBs. It would serve as a convergence area for 
assistance to ARCs and non-ARC barangays by multiple agencies and facilitate agribusiness 
development.

3.  National Policies and Plans 
16.  The  MTPDP  (2004–2010),  which  is  anchored  in  the  President’s  10-point  agenda,24 
intends to pursue a more holistic approach to reducing poverty by (i) substantially expanding the 
production base and breaking out from subsistence agriculture to increase and diversify the 
marketable surplus of the farm; (ii) raising production and distribution efficiency to improve 
quality,  competitiveness,  and  prices  of  agricultural  products;  and  (iii)  promoting  equitable 
distribution  of  production  and  productivity  gains  complemented  by  good  governance  and 
institutional reforms.   
 
17.  The program strategies laid out in the MTPDP involve the identification and prioritization 
of  prime  and  semi-prime  agrarian  reform  lands  and  adjacent  areas  for  agribusiness 
development and employment generation. The Government recently announced a program for 
support to agriculture-based export zones using prime agrarian lands. With respect to CARP, 
these strategic measures are to be complemented by capacity development for ARBs and other 
segments  of  the  rural  poor  in  the  ARCs  and  their  vicinity,  and  their  community-based 
organizations or cooperatives.  
 
18.  DAR  is  pursuing  the  implementation  of  land  tenure  improvement  and  provision  of 
essential support services in the ARCs in line with the MTPDP’s strategy to reduce poverty 
through  land  reform,  improved  land  use  and  management,  improved  access  to  essential 
services, and preferential access to social services and support groups by vulnerable groups. 
 
4.  Decentralization  
19.  The  enactment  of  the  Local  Government  Code  in  1991  triggered  the  devolution  of 
authority  and  responsibilities  from  the  national  government  to  the  LGUs  for  developing, 
financing, and managing development programs and projects. However, many LGUs still lack 
capacity to become effective service providers to their rural populations. In addition, there are 
weaknesses in governance that need to be addressed. These include weak revenue generation, 
poor tax collection, and lack of proper financial controls and accountability, among others.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Constraints and Opportunities  
1.  CARP Impact Assessment 
20.  The  enactment  of  the  Comprehensive  Agrarian  Reform  legislation  was  the 
Government’s key strategy for enhancing access to land by some 4 million farmers who are to 
benefit from agrarian reform.25 Assessing the outcomes and impacts of CARP can provide 
significant inputs into policy-related decision-making. In 2003, an in-depth study was conducted 
of the effectiveness of CARP in meeting its goals and reducing poverty.26 In addition, a study of 
CARP’s impact on poverty reduction was carried out in 2007.27 The results demonstrate the 
difficulties in  trying  to  assess  the  impacts  of  a  program  as  large  and  complex  as  CARP. 
Attribution is problematic because households and communities respond to a multiplicity of

governance.

and marketing outlets; (iii) weak farmer organizations; (iv) lack of support services; and (v) rural infrastructure.

7
factors rather than a single source of influence. Various factors have also led to the persistence 
of inequality and rural poverty. The CARP impact assessment in 2003, which was supported by 
a number of agencies, covered the program implementation in the first 12 years. It addressed 
impacts at the household, community, sector, and economy-wide levels. The 2007 study is 
focused on assessing the overall impact of CARP in terms of achieving its aims and objectives, 
and areas which need further support and strengthening. 
 
21.  Studies  to  provide  more  contemporary  analysis  are  currently  ongoing,  aimed  at 
reexamining the earlier findings in light of new data. While the conclusive findings of these 
studies  are  not  yet  available,  the  indicative  findings  show  that  wherever  CARP  has  been 
properly implemented through ARCs, the program has strengthened the formation of social, 
physical, and human capital, and developed the entrepreneurial capacities of the ARBs. Gains 
include greater ownership by farmers of their lands, improved tenure security through leasehold, 
and reduced share tenancy. There have been improvements in access to basic social services 
as a result of the ARC strategy. It also shows that more ARBs now belong to cooperatives than 
ever before. Sustainability of ARC organizations is a cause for concern, underscoring the need 
for  ensuring  their  long-term  ability  to  plan  and  undertake  commercial  and  other  activities 
autonomously. Similarly, the need to expand the outreach of support services to the greater 
number of ARBs still not covered by the program has led to the ARC cluster approach. Rural 
infrastructure availability to ARBs is found to have increased substantially, for example, a 30% 
increase in irrigation service area for total rice area in ARCs and a 22% increase in non-ARC 
barangays. However, it was also found that crop yields could be improved through better 
technology and extension support. Based on an analysis of more than 50 proxy indicators of 
welfare, the study found that while per capita expenditures on welfare have increased both in 
ARCs and non-ARC barangays, the ARC households have a higher per capita expenditure on 
welfare. CARP has led to higher real per capita incomes; and compared to non-ARBs, ARBs 
are found to have higher incomes and lower poverty incidence. Poverty incidence declined 
somewhat more in ARCs than in non-ARC barangays. About 70% of the total number of ARBs 
in  target  ARCs  covered  by  support  services  under  program  beneficiary  development,  the 
Government’s  Agrarian  Reform  Fund,  and  foreign-funded  projects,  are  found  to  have  an 
average annual income higher than the national poverty line. 
 
22.  The assessments also point out that merely being an ARB does not improve chances of 
overcoming poverty. What matters is the length of time as an ARB and inclusion in an ARC 
(covered by program beneficiary development on foreign-assisted projects), which considerably 
improve chances of poverty reduction. They emphasize that landless workers in ARCs and 
ARBs outside ARCs remained comparatively poor. The studies clearly brought out the need to 
implement CARP in a holistic manner and to develop inclusionary approaches toward the 
landless poor living in the ARCs. This can help reduce social conflict considerably.28  
 
C.  Lessons Learned  
1.  CARP Impact Assessment 
23.  The CARP impact assessments discussed above show that there is a need to improve 
the implementation of land acquisition and distribution with regard to the timely completion of 
land  acquisition,  cadastral  surveys,  requisite  inspection  and  verifications  by  DENR,  and 
issuance  of  secure  and  appropriate  land  titles.  This  will  require  improved  working  and 
coordination among DAR, DENR, LGUs, and courts, among others, to reduce delays and 
challenges to the process and to complete land acquisition and distribution. The incomes of 
ARBs  in  ARCs  can  be  increased  by  working  on  improving  their  nonfarm  incomes. 
Mainstreaming ARBs into the programs of support service agencies and LGUs can help to 
                                                 
28  DAR. 2003. CARP Impact Assessment Studies 1. Manila.

8   
provide greater sustainability to ARB income improvements. There is opportunity for improved 
productivity through improved technology, along with increased irrigation availability. There is a 
serious  need  to  promote  other  options  for  credit  to  farmers.  Nongovernment  organization 
(NGO)-based initiatives need to be expanded. Collective CLOAs covering at least 1,614,273 ha 
nationwide are in need of separation. The Project will build upon these lessons emerging from 
the CARP impact assessment. 
 
2.  Agrarian Reform Communities Project  
 
24.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  assistance  for  the  Agrarian  Reform 
Communities Project (ARCP) in 1998.29 The project closed on 1 December 2007. It provided a 
number of important lessons both for project design and strategy. Decentralization of project 
implementation  to  DAR  regional  offices,  LGUs,  and  ARCs,  was  useful  in  raising  local 
commitment and resources for subproject planning and execution. LGUs have been forthcoming 
with regard to providing services and resources. A remarkable success of the ARCP has been 
in building strong ARC organizations and promoting the start-up of agribusiness activities. The 
Land Bank of the Philippines’ problems associated with attempting to provide credit to rural 
borrower with little collateral and poor credit histories, demonstrated the need to build the 
capacity of ARBs and ARC organizations for better financial management and accountability. 
Entrepreneurial skills and management capabilities of target ARCs, cooperatives, and farmer 
associations were built through on-the-job training by national experts hired by the project. 
Diversification of farm production through demonstration and sharing of know-how and inputs 
has shown ARBs the way to move from low-value crops to higher-value products and better 
markets. Irrigation development has improved crop yields and intensification of cropping. One of 
the most significant lessons of the project has been the importance of providing improved 
physical infrastructure and transportation to target ARCs to connect them with bigger and more 
distant markets and social services. Their lack of credit constrains ARBs from taking better 
advantage of these. 
 
25.  The experience in project implementation and management gained under ARCP points 
to the need to ensure timely availability of adequate budget cover for planned project activities 
by the Government. It also underscores the need to avoid premature loan cancellations by ADB. 
The  experience  further  demonstrates  the  need  to  mainstream  project  implementation  and 
improve governance at all levels. Improved financial and fiduciary responsibility of LGUs has to 
be ensured through capacity development and careful supervision by the DAR central office. It 
establishes the need to reduce the geographical spread of areas to be covered by the project. It 
further  demonstrates  the  need  to  prevent  elite  capture  of  project  benefits  though  greater 
empowerment of ARC organizations and adoption of a more inclusive approach to the other 
segments of the rural poor in target areas. It demonstrates the need for greater efforts to build 
the financial management capacity of ARB organizations, particularly cooperatives; expand their 
membership and services; and link ARBs with microfinance institutions, banks, and private 
sector organizations that can provide credit, processing support, and marketing links.  
 
26.  ARCP II will build on the momentum created by the positive outcomes of the ARCP, 
while  addressing  the  gaps  in  project  design  and  lessons  learned  from  the  CARP  impact 
assessments.  
 
3.  Lessons Learned from Other Externally Assisted Projects

communities, through community–driven development. ARCP II will build on these lessons. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome   
28.  The long-term impact of the Project is to enable ARBs in about 152 selected ARCs and 
11 ARC clusters in 19 provinces30 to reduce poverty, and have sustained improvements in 
incomes and quality of life. The Project outcome includes improved capabilities and well-being 
of poor and marginalized groups in the target communities. This outcome will be pursued 
through  the  design  and  implementation  of  an  integrated  and  complementary  package  of 
development investments, involving support for community–driven development (CDD), support 
to  new  and  expanded  ARC  organizations  and  their  business-oriented  activities,  increased 
effective participation of the poor in community planning and decision-making, agri-enterprise 
development, infrastructural support, and mainstreaming of project management.  
 
29.  Target area selection was based on both poverty and identifiable economic potential-
based criteria. At the provincial level, the lesson of ARCP to keep the geographical spread 
manageable was kept in mind. Poverty assessments showed that three quarters of the poor are 
in the Mindanao and the Visayan regions. Targeting these regions is essential to address 
resource inequalities as well as provision of necessary infrastructure and support services for 
the rural poor. It is also important to correct the regional imbalances in income opportunities 
among the regions in the country. As agreed by DAR and ADB and in consultation with the DAR 
regional  and  provincial  officials,  the  selection  of  the  eligible  provinces  was  based  on  the 
following criteria: 
 
(i)  Provinces with the highest rural poverty incidence.  
(ii)  Provinces in the southern half of the Philippines that are included in the ADB

(iii)  Provinces with at least four ARCs that have not received financial assistance for 
infrastructure from foreign-assisted projects of DAR.  
(iv)  LGUs’ willingness to cooperate with the ARCs and assurances of inter-LGU 
cooperation. 
 
30.  Based  on  the  latest  official  poverty  data,  nineteen  of  the  poorest  provinces  were 
selected, including six in the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (ARMM). ARCs and ARC 
clusters were selected based on the following criteria: (i) no earlier infrastructure support from 
other  foreign-assisted  projects  of  DAR;  (ii)  demonstration  of  income-earning  potential;  (iii) 
achievement by the ARC of at least level 2 in the ARC level of development assessment, which 
indicates that the ARC has commenced on its own development initiatives; (iv) at least one ARC 
organization having reached an organizational maturity level of 3, signifying capacity to engage 
in economic activities; (v) at least 50% of land acquisition and distribution activities completed, 
indicating that ARBs have tenurial security; (vi) potential for access to markets and facilities; and 
(vii) demonstrated LGU support. In the 19 provinces selected, a total of 152 ARCs fulfilled these 
criteria. ARC clusters are being identified in a phased manner to target the candidate ARCs that 
have  several  barangays  with  large  numbers  of  ARBs  not  yet  assisted.  ARC  clusters  with 
development plans already prepared are being prioritized by the LGUs and DAR. 
 
B.  Project Outputs 
31.  To achieve the outcomes of poverty reduction and sustainable livelihoods, the Project 
will support the following outputs32:  
 
(i)   CDD consisting of  
(a)   social capital formation for community organizing and participation, 
(b)   participatory detailed ARC planning,  
(c)   organizational development of community organizations, and  
(d)  improved LGU capacity for better governance.  
(ii)   Agriculture and enterprise development including  
(a)   transfer of technology,  
(b)   entrepreneurship development among ARC organizations,  
(c)   improved linkages between the private sector and ARC organizations 
leading to increased investments into rural areas for growth,  
(d)   community-based savings and lending groups, and 
(e)    land tenure improvement.  
(iii)   Rural infrastructure development.  
(iv)   Project implementation and management.  
 
1.  Community Driven Development  
32.  The objective of this output is to mobilize, organize, and strengthen communities and 
local institutions, through the use of a CDD approach throughout the Project. It aims to prepare 
local communities and people's organizations for their active participation in the design of 
poverty reduction activities supported by the Project. Greater participation by the poor will be 
encouraged to prevent capture of project benefits by the elite. Support will go to organizing of 
inclusive membership-based groups, developing their capacity, and improving LGU governance.  
 
33.  The output will consist of the following subcomponents: (i) support to social capital 
formation; (ii) participatory detailed ARC planning; (iii) organizational development of community 
organizations; and (iv) improved LGU capacity for better governance.  
                                                 
31 ADB. 2005. Country Strategy and Program 2005-2007, Philippines. Manila. 
32 These are reflected in Appendix 1.

11
 
a.  Support to Social Capital Formation  
34.  The objective of this subcomponent is to prepare and strengthen communities and local 
institutions for their informed participation throughout the Project, to improve the sustainability of 
project investments. A CDD approach33 will be used to engage the poor in the target ARCs and 
ARC clusters in identifying priority needs and constraints, as well as subprojects to address 
them. The activities to be supported will be the following: (i) mobilization of communities and (ii) 
building socially inclusive membership-based organizations of ARBs, non-ARBs, and landless 
workers in the target areas. The Project will provide support through NGOs and civil society 
organizations, which will deploy trained community organizers, backstopped by expert NGO 
staff, to work in all target barangays. This subcomponent will also help to identify the training 
and  capacity  development  needs  of  ARB  organizations  and  to  draw  up  training  and 
development plans for the ARCs. 
 
b.  Participatory ARC Planning   
35.  The second set of activities will include detailed ARC and ARC cluster planning. The first 
step after start-up of the project implementation will be the training of planning teams at the 
provincial level. Training will be provided on community–driven development and safeguard 
policies  by  subject  specialists  and  NGOs.  This  will  be  followed  by  the  development  of 
comprehensive ARC plans to be prepared by communities, represented in barangay CARP 
implementing teams, with technical support from the project teams. The planning process will be 
fully participatory and inclusive of vulnerable groups, and it will be assisted by the NGOs. Close 
attention  will  need  to  be  paid  to  identification  of  marketing  opportunities.  The  Project  will 
facilitate LGU participation in ARC planning and the incorporation of ARC plans with rural 
development plans of LGUs.  
 
c.  ARC and LGU Organizational Development for Improved 
Governance 
36.  This subcomponent will seek to strengthen local community-based organizations and 
local government agencies working with them under the Project, to make them more effective in 
planning, implementing, monitoring, and sustaining activities within their own areas. This will 
reinvigorate the provincial, municipal, and barangay CARP implementing teams, and the LGU 
entities working with them. It will develop and train ARC cooperatives, microfinance groups, and 
farmer associations. It will also establish user associations for social services and infrastructure 
(barangay water user and irrigator associations, among others). 
 
37.  The  subcomponent  will  improve  local  governance  and  accountability  of  LGUs  by 
providing training34 on fiduciary policies and management, as well as on safeguard policies, 
among other areas of capacity development. To deal with the frequent changes in the LGUs 
because of evolving political processes, the Project will provide training on a continuing basis to 
ensure the longer-term capacity of the LGUs to provide assistance to the ARCs. The Project will 
involve  the  legislative  branch  of  the  LGUs  in  project  implementation  to  safeguard  against 
possible changes in the LGUs.

2.  Agriculture and Enterprise Development 
38.  The purpose of the agriculture and enterprise development output is to provide strategic 
support services to participating ARCs and ARC clusters to (i) generate sustained increases in 
agricultural production and productivity; (ii) increase economic activities and value-added in the 
target  areas;  and  (iii)  pilot  ARC  connectivity  strategies.  This  output  is  expected  improve 
livelihoods through better market orientation and value addition by ARBs. The output consists of 
four subcomponents: (i) agricultural productivity improvement, (ii) enterprise development, (iii) 
land tenure improvement, and (iv) enhanced access to rural financial services.  
 
a.  Agricultural Productivity Improvement 
39.  This subcomponent will enable ARBs and non-ARB small and marginal farmers to move 
from subsistence production to market-oriented surplus generation. It will provide assistance to 
ARCs based on their needs and priorities identified in the detailed ARC plans. It will accordingly 
support training, demonstrations, and cross-learning visits by farmer groups for peer group 
learning. Among the types of demonstrations and training to be supported are  
 
(i)  increased productivity through introduction of improved crop varieties; 
(ii)  improved farming practices to increase yields and cropping intensity—this will 
include  sloping  land  technology,  organic  crop  production,  certified  seed 
production, among others;  
(iii)  integrated pest management; 
(iv)  enhanced  access  to  and  installation  of  irrigation  systems  (under  the  rural 
infrastructure component);  
(v)  crop diversification through environment-friendly farming systems (multistory and 
rotational cropping); 
(vi)  improved post-production handling, especially of perishable produce, to minimize 
losses; 
(vii)  improved marketability products by improving their quality and safety (not harmful 
to consumers); and 
(viii)  study tours of farmer groups. 
 
b.  Agri-Enterprise and Market Development  
40.  This  subcomponent  will  support  better  integration  of  market  considerations  into 
subprojects under the Project. Proposals identified in the ARC plans will need to include market 
assessments  and  marketing  plans.  Business  advisory  units  will  provide  services  to  ARC 
organizations. These advisory units will be established at the provincial level, initially within the 
DAR provincial office, to be turned over eventually to the LGU. A market information system will 
also be set up at the provincial level in collaboration with the Department of Agriculture’s Bureau 
of Agricultural Statistics.  
 
41.  To facilitate the development of large agribusiness areas, the Project will support ARC 
cluster development. The target ARCs will be the starting points from which to initiate cluster 
activities  in  surrounding  barangays.  The  Project  will  focus  on  activities  that  can  clearly 
strengthen the backward and forward linkages between production, processing, and marketing. 
About 11 ARC clusters are likely to be included under ARCP II with a phased approach. ARC 
cluster coordinators with appropriate private sector development background will be appointed 
at DAR regional offices.  
 
c.  Land Tenure Improvement  
42.  The Project will support improvements in land titles in agrarian reform lands, with a view 
to strengthening ideas of ownership and commitment among ARBs to improving their lands. The

13
land area covered by collective CLOAs amounts to about 59% of the total area distributed in the 
selected ARCs (outside of ARMM). Land tenure improvement will be undertaken primarily in the 
target ARCs where about 55,000 ha will need to be surveyed for subdivision and/or stabilization 
of titles, as per the cropping plans prepared as part of the detailed ARC planning process. About 
22,000 ARBs will be covered under this. 
 
43.   Support  for  land  tenure  improvement  will  include  social  preparation,  surveys,  and 
separation  of  individual  titles,  stabilization  of  land  titles  of  ARBs.  Social  preparation  for 
separation of collective issuance of individual CLOA separation will be provided through the 
community–driven development approach. Surveys and separation of individual titles will be 
implemented with DAR as the prime mover.  
  
d.  Improved Access to Sustainable Rural Financial Services 
44.  There is need to mitigate the negative effects on productivity of ARBs’ high levels of 
credit-related  dependence  on  traders  and  moneylenders.35  The  Project  will  contract  with 
suitable NGOs, civil society organizations, and microfinance institutions to work with interested 
ARCs  in  setting  up  self-selected,  socially  homogenous  people’s  groups  to  help  develop 
community-based  microfinance  activities.  The  Project  will  work  with  selected  microfinance 
institutions to develop suitable options for farmers’ credit needs. 
 
3.  Rural Infrastructure Development 
45.  Rural infrastructure is critical to the ability of ARCs and ARC clusters to participate in 
market-oriented agriculture and agribusiness promotion. To enhance ARC connectivity and 
promote development of agribusiness lands, the rural infrastructure development output will aim 
to (i) reduce transportation time and haulage costs of rural produce; (ii) reduce cost of farm 
inputs;  (iii) increase  availability  of  irrigation  to  enhance  crop  production;  (iv)  promote  crop 
diversification; (v) increase cropping intensity and improve yields; and (vi) reduce post-harvest 
losses and transport damage. In addition, because most ARCs have difficulties accessing clean 
water, this subcomponent will also provide priority social infrastructure in order to (i) reduce 
incidence  of  waterborne  diseases;  (ii)  generate  time  savings  for  more  productive  use;  (iii) 
reduce health-related expenses; (iv) improve community hygiene and public health; and (v) 
reduce the vulnerability of the rural poor to various types of crises by improving access to 
emergency services. 
 
46.  The  Project  will  adopt  a  community–driven  development  approach  to  subproject 
identification during the ARC detailed planning, to ensure that interventions provided by the 
Project realistically address the needs of the ARCs.  
 
47.  The main outputs will include the following subcomponents:  
 
(i)  Rural  access  infrastructure.  Rehabilitation  and  selective  construction  of 
critically  needed  barangay  or  farm-to-market  roads  and  their  associated 
structures, single-lane concrete bridges and low-level crossings, access trails, 
footpaths, and hanging foot bridges in upland areas; 
(ii)  Small-scale irrigation. Construction and rehabilitation of small-flow communal 
irrigation  schemes,  small  water  impounding  projects,  small  farm  reservoirs, 
shallow tube wells, and drip irrigation schemes for high-value crops; 
(iii)  Post-harvest facilities. Provision of warehouses and solar driers;

(iv)  Potable Water Supply System (PWS). Construction of PWS to include levels I 
and II;36 and 
(v)  Other social infrastructure. Construction and /or rehabilitation of   multipurpose 
buildings,  tribal  halls,  school  room  units,  daycare  centers,  barangay  health 
stations,  and  small-scale  flood  protection  works.  These  sub-projects  will  be 
considered only where the lack of such facilities would jeopardize the creation of 
an enabling environment for sustainable poverty reduction. Indigenous peoples 
communities will be given the highest priority in the provision of other social 
infrastructure.   
 
48.  Subprojects shall be planned and selected in accordance with the project guidelines 
agreed between the Borrower and ADB. The project guidelines shall include, among others, the 
following selection criteria: (i) prioritization by poor rural communities through the community–
driven development approach; (ii) concurrence by the LGU; (iii) willingness on the part of LGUs 
to put up the required equity in accordance with the Borrower’s National Government and Local 
Government Unit Cost Sharing Policy approved by the Investment Coordination Committee on 
12 December 2002, and to operate and maintain the facilities in partnership with appropriate 
ARC organizations; (iv) LGU willingness to carry out the necessary surveys (including a census 
of affected persons in instances of land acquisition and adverse impacts, a land acquisition 
survey (if required), and social surveys), individual subproject feasibility studies by which the 
technical and economic viability are verified, and detailed engineering design that includes all 
required clearances; (v) preparation of the land acquisition and resettlement plans (LARPs), if 
required, or a summary discussion of land report in cases of no land acquisition, (vi) willingness 
of LGUs to abide by ADB and government procurement safeguard and anticorruption policies, 
and to enforce proper financial and fiduciary management; (vii) commitment of LGUs to resolve 
any social or environmental problems; (viii) willingness of the LGUs and ARCs to promote 
organizations within the ARCs to operate and maintain the facilities; (ix) availability of project 
resources; and (x) no financing of proposed subprojects from any other foreign or local projects.  
 
4.  Project Implementation and Management 
49.  Efficient project implementation and management will be ensured by providing resources 
to support the management structure, which will be fully mainstreamed at the national, regional, 
provincial, and local levels. To the extent possible, all project implementation and management 
structures will be established within existing national and provincial government institutions. 
Regular DAR staff will be redeployed to assist in project implementation. The output will include 
consultant  advisory  services  related  to  project  management,  CDD,  safeguard  policies,37 
fiduciary responsibility, agri-enterprise development, microfinance and rural credit promotion, 
infrastructure  development,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  extension  training,  gender  and 
development, and environment management, among others. 
 
C.  Special Features 
50.  Socially Inclusive Development. The Project is expected to stimulate participatory and 
inclusive social development. It includes a number of measures aimed at supporting community 
mobilization including organizing, training, capacity development in participatory design and 
implementation; improving capacity to access institutional finance; and building up community-
based savings and credit groups, among others. Through these, the Project is expected to 
improve the local decision-making of the rural poor, reduce dependence on moneylenders and 
traders, reduce share tenancy, enable community monitoring and implementation, and improve 
ARBs’ and other poor farmers’ incomes through access to the open market instead of tied factor

E.  Financing Plan  
52.  The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $70  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources (OCR), including price contingencies and financing charges during implementation to 
help finance the project.  The total project cost is estimated $208.4 million. About $70 million of 
such financing will come from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, while $30 million will come from 
OFID funds to be administered by ADB. The ADB ordinary capital resources portion of the loan 
will have a 25.5 year term, including a grace period of 6.5 years, an interest rate determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility plus a 
0.20% net lending spread; the commitment charge calculated at a 0.15% rate is levied on 
undisbursed  loan  balance;  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  set  forth  in  the  Loan 
Agreement. The Government has provided ADB with (i) the reasons for its decision to borrow 
under the ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis of these terms and conditions, and 
(ii) an undertaking that these choices were its own independent decision and not made in 
reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. The OFID portion of the loan will have a 
20-year maturity, including a 5-year grace period, a 1% service charge per annum, and 3% 
interest. 
 
 53.  Proceeds from the ADB ordinary capital resources portion of the loan will finance project 
activities covering approximately 127 ARCs in the target provinces identified for the Project 
while the OFID loan will finance project activities for approximately 25 ARCs in the ARMM and

16   
or other poor areas.38 The loan proceeds from the ADB loan and the ADB-administered OFID 
loan will finance 48.0% of the project cost. By source, ADB ordinary capital resources loan will 
finance 33.6%, while the OFID loan will finance 14.4% of the total project cost. The Government 
will finance about 52.0% of the total cost, equivalent to $108.4 million. The Government will fund 
a part of the cost of civil works, rural finance, and recurrent costs including salaries, operations 
and maintenance costs, and financing charges. The amount includes $52.4 million from the 
budgetary  appropriations  of  DAR  and  $56.0  million  from  equity  contribution  of  LGUs 
participating in the project. National government policy limits its grant financing of infrastructure 
projects devolved to LGUs to a maximum of 50% of cost.39 The policy applies to the rural 
infrastructure facilities covered by the project. The nature of the LGU equity may be in the form 
of cash or combined cash and monetized in-kind contributions, such as use of equipment and 
materials owned by the LGU. It is agreed that the LGUs may enroll in a reform program with 
identified goals and measurable benchmarks. Based on satisfactory evidence of their meeting 
the targets, the LGUs may have 20% of their contribution refunded to them by the national 
government. Government contribution includes an estimated $6 million credit portfolio to be 
tapped from public and private microfinance institutions in support of the project’s microfinance 
assistance to intensify and/or diversify agricultural production and promote rural  enterprise 
development in the ARCs. 
 
54.  Contributions from project beneficiaries constitute about 5% of LGU equity, mainly in the 
form of donated labor time and indigenous materials. Savings and/or capital share through 
membership in cooperatives may also be required or utilized as beneficiary’s equity in availing 
microfinance or the internally generated savings of the community-based microfinance groups.

F.  Implementation Arrangements 
1.  Project Management 
55.  Executing Agency. DAR will be the Executing Agency (EA) of the Project.40 DAR will 
supervise  the  implementation  of  the  Project  through  its  Foreign-Assisted  Projects  Office 
(FAPsO), in collaboration with other operational units within the department as well as CARP 
implementing partner agencies and oversight agencies. FAPsO will oversee the coordination of 
project  implementation,  review,  monitoring,  and  evaluation.  It  will  submit  monthly  and/or 
quarterly financial and progress reports to ADB and oversight agencies. It will manage the 
Project  and  be  responsible  for  delivery  of  project  outputs.  The  EA  will  make  necessary

budgetary  arrangements  for  the  Project’s  counterpart  funds  to  be  estimated  12  months  in 
advance of the anticipated expenditure and ensure that such funds will be allocated in the 
respective national, provincial, and municipal budgets and released in a timely manner and in 
adequate amounts to allow efficient project implementation, operations, and maintenance. 
 
56.  Project Executive Committee. DAR will work under the supervision and guidance of 
the project executive committee (PEC), which will be set up and chaired by the DAR Secretary. 
The DAR Undersecretary designated as the project implementation officer (PIO) for FAPsO will 
act as vice chair. The PEC will include representatives of oversight agencies and partner 
agencies and/or their respective successors.41 Ex-officio members shall include representatives 
from involved DAR units and the ADB. It will meet at least once every quarter in year 1 and 
every 6 months thereafter. It will review and approve annual work plans and budget, flow of 
funds, cost-sharing with LGUs, use of consultant services, progress monitoring, and all other 
relevant project activities. There shall be a secretariat, to be headed by the national project 
coordinator (NPC) of ARCPII, which will handle the technical and administrative requirements of 
the  committee  under  the  supervision  and  guidance  of  the  director,  project  development 
management staff (PDMS) and FAPsO monitoring and evaluation (M&E) staff. The secretariat 
will coordinate committee meetings and timely preparation and submission of all project-related 
documents for review by the committee, prepare and disseminate the minutes of committee 
meetings and decisions made by the committee, and handle any other responsibilities allocated 
to it by the committee. 
 
57.  Under the office of the FAPsO, a national project coordination office (NPCO) for ARCP 
II, to be headed by the national project coordinator for ARCPII, will be set up to manage the 
Project and to supervise, monitor, and coordinate project implementation.42 The NPC for ARCP 
II will be based here. He or she will be assisted by the regular FAPsO staff and some 13 
national  consultants  in  the  areas  of  project  management,  administration,  finance,  and 
accounting, among others. The NPC for ARCP II, who will report to the PIO FAPsO, will also be 
assisted by a rural development and fiduciary adviser (international consultant) to be engaged 
for about 24 person-months over the project implementation period.43 The NPC will be regularly 
assisted  by  the  project  management  adviser,  (national  consultant)  to  be  engaged  for 
approximately 36 person months over the project period. 
   
58.  Implementing  Agencies  and  Specialized  Agencies  Providing  Assistance.  
Implementing agencies will include all participating municipal LGU and DAR offices at the 
regional and provincial levels. CARP implementing partner agencies such as the Department of 
Agriculture (DA) and Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR), Department 
of Public Works and Highways (DPWH) and specialized agencies such as the National Irrigation 
Administration (NIA) and National Commission on Indigenous Peoples (NCIP) will also support 
the Project. The NCIP, NIA and other specialized agencies whose inputs may be realized for the 
project, will each sign with DAR a memorandum of agreement, which will spell out their roles, 
responsibilities, and budget for implementation of specific project activities. DAR-ARMM will

reform officers, assisted by technical experts and administrative and financial specialists from 
the LGU, as well as staff from the regional offices and provincial project managers' offices, will 
be responsible for project implementation at ARC and municipal levels. In close collaboration 
with the MARO, the LPO will serve as the base unit for all project interventions in the ARCs 
within  the  municipality.    The  LPO  will  be  responsible  for  ARC  planning,  agri-enterprise 
development  activities,  community–driven  development  support  programs,  and  rural 
infrastructure  subproject  planning,  and  provision  of  required  equity  for  the  relevant  project 
activities. The local project offices shall coordinate and monitor project implementation and 
address project-related concerns at the municipal and ARC levels, in close collaboration with 
the MAROs. At the LPO level, the municipal engineer’s office will be the designated project unit 
for infrastructure development, while the municipal agriculture office will be responsible for 
agriculture, agri-enterprise development, and livelihoods development activities.   
 
61.  Implementation Arrangements in the ARMM. For project activities to be carried out in 
the ARMM, a regional project office will be established prior to loan effectiveness. The DAR-
ARMM secretary will be the regional project manager, responsible for reporting and coordinating 
with the ARMM regional governor. The DAR-ARMM assistant secretary of operations will be the 
ARMM  regional deputy project manager. The management and operations of the regional 
project office will be mainstreamed in the DAR-ARMM office. Municipal-level LGUs will play 
important roles in planning and implementing ARC plans and approved subprojects. The Project 
will  be  implemented  in  close  consultation  with  local  community  leaders  to  ensure  social 
inclusion and acceptance, with lasting impacts on peace and security. 
 
62.  Fund Flows to ARMM. ARCP II funds will flow directly to DAR-ARMM through DAR. 
Since ARCP II is a national project, DAR central office will transfer funds directly to DAR-ARMM 
for activities related to CDD, ARC planning, capacity development, agri-enterprise development, 
land tenure improvement, rural financial systems development, and project management. For 
rural infrastructure subprojects, the Municipal Development Fund Office of the Department of 
Finance will transfer funds directly to participating LGUs, based on the cost-sharing agreement 
between them and the national government. In the context of the weaker LGUs, particularly in 
the ARMM, the Project will provide training in fiduciary aspects, financial management, and 
procurement.   
   
63.  Technical Review and Approval Committees. To mainstream and decentralize the 
review and approval process of subprojects under ARCP II, the process of technical review and 
approval  of  subprojects  will  be  shared  at  the  regional  and  national  levels,  depending  on

Project Management Structure.
