E.  Development of a Land Acquisition and Resettlement Plan 
  1.   LARP Scope 
 
19.  A LARP is essential for each subproject where involuntary resettlement impacts are 
identified. This will cover  
 
(i)  identification of potentially affected persons;  
(ii)  identification of kinds and extent of impacts on land and other physical assets, 
non-land  assets,  livelihoods,  and  community  assets,  including  infrastructure, 
common property, and resources; 
(iii)  mechanisms  for  deciding  on  compensation  based  on  the  principles  of 
replacement  cost  of  land  and  non-land  assets,  relocation  and  transition 
assistance, compensation for lost business and livelihoods, reestablishment of 
business and livelihoods, assistance for starting new livelihoods, and assistance 
to  rebuild  social  capital,  social  services,  common  property  resources,  and 
infrastructure;  
(iv)  processes for communication;  
(v)  procedures for valuation of land and other assets;  
(vi)  negotiation processes for sale and compensation;  
(vii)  documentation of processes; 
(viii)  monitoring of the process through the municipal CARP implementing team and 
safeguard specialists;  
(ix)  generation and implementation of a communication plan to inform, both initially 
and on a continuous basis, potential affected persons of the possible project 
impacts and their rights and responsibilities in relation to compensation; and 
(x)  grievance redress mechanisms made available to the community to convey to 
the  municipal  LGU  related  complaints  and  concerns,  addressing  each  in  a 
manner that is transparent and equitable, recording in detail all complaints and 
the actions taken. 
 
2.  LARP Formulation 
20.  The LARP is a plan that identifies and addresses any adverse social and economic 
impacts of the ARC and ARC cluster subprojects. In summary, the LARP will 
 
(i)  provide an assessment of the impacts that each subproject component may have 
on the local communities; 
(ii)  quantify in monetary terms the private and public assets that will be affected and 
acquired for each subproject component; 
(iii)  provide a safeguard mechanism by which voluntary donation of land and/or land 
improvements are not abused; 
(iv)  present  a  plan  that  will  ensure  the  timely  acquisition  of  assets,  payment  of 
compensation,  and  delivery  of  other  benefits  to  affected  persons,  including 
measures that will ensure the orderly and timely relocation of severely affected 
households when warranted; 
(v)  provide a plan on how the affected persons will be involved in each stage of the 
subproject, including the implementation of the LARP; and

Appendix 7  53
(vi)  determine the required resources needed to implement the LARP, and cost-
sharing  arrangements  among  the  implementing  agencies  and  subproject 
beneficiaries. 
 
21.  There are two basic formats for the LARP—detailed and overview—depending on the 
scale and magnitude of the adverse social impacts of a subproject component. The full LARP is 
required if more than 200 people will experience resettlement effects. In addition, the following 
conditions will likewise require the preparation of a full resettlement plan: 
 
(i)  100 or more affected persons are indigenous peoples or in some way vulnerable, 
such as households headed by women and persons without legal title; or 
(ii)  50  or  more  affected  persons  are  particularly  vulnerable,  such  as  hunter-
gatherers. 
 
22.  The short version of the LARP will be required if the number of affected persons does 
not reach the level of more than 200 pesos. For the ARCP II, it is expected that the shorter 
version would be required in cases where involuntary resettlement impacts are likely to occur. In 
the event that there are no resettlement issues, then only a summary discussion on land 
acquisition and resettlement will be required to be annexed to the subproject feasibility study.  
 
F.  Communications and Submission Processes 
23.  In line with ADB’s Public Communications Policy (2005), all documents pertaining to the 
involuntary resettlement policy and the IRF for all subprojects will be made available to the 
public in a variety of ways. The Project will develop a communications plan for the IRF and 
individual subproject-related documents, which will include translations of the documents into 
the local language and use of leaflets, brochures, radio, local media, and NGOs, among others. 
 
24.  Once the LARP has been completed and approved by the RSAC, it will be submitted to 
the NPCO and ADB for review and approval. After ADB approval is obtained, it will be submitted 
along with the detailed project proposal and feasibility study to the ARCP II regional and/or 
national project review coordinating committee for approval. The barangay CARP implementing 
team  CSGS  will  formally  submit  requirements  for  compensation  to  the  barangay  CARP 
implementing  team  and  the  local  project  office,  to  be  considered  by  the  municipal  CARP 
implementing team, so that funds can be allocated for the compensation package.

54  Appendix 8 
SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENT EXAMINATION  
 
A.  Introduction 
1.  This report is a summary of the initial environmental examination (IEE) based on the 
feasibility  study  conducted  in  sample  sites  for  the  proposed  second  Agrarian  Reform 
Communities  Project  (ARCP  II)  through  site  assessments  and  consultation  with  the 
stakeholders in the national government agencies (Department of Environment and Natural 
Resources [DENR] Environmental Management Bureau, Department of Agriculture, National 
Irrigation  Administration);  local  government  units  (LGUs)  at  the  provincial,  municipal,  and 
barangay levels; and the communities at the project sites. 
 
B.  Description of the Project 
2.  ARCP II is a follow-on project of the Agrarian Reform Communities Project (ARCP) of 
the Department of Agrarian Reform (DAR) with funding from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). The specific outcome of this Project is the long-lasting improvement in the capabilities 
and well-being of the poor and marginalized groups in the target communities. 
 
3.  To achieve this outcome, the Project would have the following outputs: (i) community 
driven development, (ii) agriculture and enterprise development, (iii) rural infrastructure support, 
and (iv) project implementation management. 
 
4.  The  rural  infrastructure  component  is  all  small-scale  projects  located  in  152  ARCs 
(clusters  of  about  five  to  six  barangays  within  an  LGU)  spread  over  municipalities  in  19 
provinces  of  southern  Philippines.  This  initial  environment  examination  is  needed  only  to 
determine the extent of impact to the immediate surroundings and environment. Under ARCP II, 
specific outputs of the rural infrastructure component include rehabilitation and construction of 
(i)  small-scale  rural  access  infrastructure  (farm-to-market  roads,  small-scale  single-lane 
concrete bridges and low-level crossings, access trails, and footpaths and hanging footbridges 
in upland areas); (ii) small-scale irrigation (small-flow communal irrigation schemes, small water 
impounding projects, small farm reservoirs, shallow tube wells, and drip irrigation schemes for 
high-value crops); (iii) post-harvest facilities (small-scale warehouses and solar driers); and (iv) 
small-scale social infrastructure facilities (potable water supply  and small-scale multipurpose 
buildings and other social facilities, if critically needed.  
 
5.  Purely public infrastructures for access and social purposes (health stations, day care 
centers, school buildings) will be turned over to the LGUs for operation and maintenance, while 
community infrastructure like irrigation schemes, warehouses, and solar driers will be operated 
and maintained by farmers’ organizations. 
 
C.  Description of the Environment 
6.  Considering the poverty reduction concerns of the Government and the strategic focus 
of ADB, ARCP II has given priority to the southern half of the Philippines. The project area will 
cover 19 provinces spread across the 6 regions in Mindanao, the Visayas, and the southern part 
of Luzon.  
 
7.  The topography of the ARC sites ranges from flat to gently rolling in and moderate rolling 
or undulating plains to hilly terrain in some of the ARC areas. A few ARCs have coastal zones 
with agrarian reform beneficiaries (ARBs) supplementing their incomes through fishing. Of the

Appendix 8  55
19 provinces, about 6 are typhoon areas, with natural calamities frequently affecting agricultural 
and fishing activities of the rural households. Low-lying ARCs, which are traversed by major 
river systems, are prone to flooding during the wet season because of deforested watershed 
areas and lack of natural drainage outlets. Soil classification in these ARCs ranges from sandy 
loam to clay loam. 
 
8.  While  some  provinces  have  protected  areas  like  forest  reserves  that  have  rare  or 
endemic wildlife species, none of the targeted ARCs are located within or near these high-
biodiversity areas. Sites that are of historical, archeological, paleontological, or architectural 
significance are also not found in these ARCs. Air quality is relatively clean because of the 
absence of major industries or geothermal emissions. 
  
9.  All the ARCs eligible for financing under ARCP II have agriculture-based economies. 
Predominant crops are coconut, corn, rain-fed rice, banana, root crops, and tree fruit. Mono-
cropping is commonly practiced, with only a few areas within coconut plantations engaged in 
intercropping. Given the constraints on agricultural productivity, the common denominator of 
ARCs under ARCP II is the high incidence of poverty compared to the rest of the provinces in 
the country. 
 
10.  In  almost  all  provinces,  provincial  roads  link  the  rural  areas  to  the  socioeconomic 
centers, services, and facilities. These roads are usually the arterial link of the municipality and 
barangays to the national highway. City and municipal roads consist mainly of cement streets 
located within the urban centers and maintained by the LGUs. Barangay roads, mostly of earth 
and gravel, serve as access to the ARCs. They are generally impassable and in need of 
rehabilitation. As a result, these ARCs are commonly inaccessible and unconnected to the 
nearest all-weather road leading to nearby urban centers. 
 
11.  Because these sites have agriculture-based economies, there are potential areas for 
irrigation development. It is estimated that about 18% of the total eligible ARC barangays will 
require development of their irrigation facilities. 
 
12.  While a majority of the provincial and municipal urban centers have existing potable 
water supply systems, the rural areas within the ARCs still derive their drinking water from 
unreliable sources like open dug wells, rivers, and creeks. However, many ARCs have easily 
available natural springs that need to be developed to provide clean and reliable potable water 
supplies to the communities. 
 
13.  Other concerns in the project areas are inaccessibility to social infrastructure, such as 
health and elementary education facilities, and lack of electricity in the remote barangays of the 
identified ARCs.        
 
D.  Potential Environmental Impact and Mitigating Measures 
1.  Environmental Issues Related to Subproject Location and Design 
14.  In general, there are no significant environmental problems associated with subproject 
locations.  There  are  no  ARCs  within  or  near  high-biodiversity  areas  or  sites  of  historical, 
archeological, paleontological, or architectural significance, so subprojects within these ARCs 
will not affect such areas.

56  Appendix 8 
15.  The  majority  of  access  infrastructure  would  involve  farm-to-market  roads  to  be 
rehabilitated and a few roads and bridges to be constructed. Individual subprojects would 
involve an average of 2 km of farm-to-market roads and about 30 linear meters of single-lane 
concrete bridges. The existing roads will be upgraded to all-weather condition without increase 
in  width  or  length.  Therefore,  no  right-of-way  problems  are  expected,  while  proposed 
construction will avoid forested areas and steep slopes.  
 
16.  The mitigating measures at the design stage would involve the detailed review of the 
location and technical specifications of the proposed access infrastructure. Initial review will be 
undertaken at the DAR regional level, and a final review will be done at the central level. 
Proposed  subprojects  located  in  environmentally  sensitive  areas  will  be  recommended  for 
relocation to alternative routes. The design of access infrastructure will adopt the standard 
specifications of the Department of Public Works and Highways, with drainage facilities and 
slope protection as necessary to ensure stability.     
 
17.  Small-scale  irrigation  schemes  will  cover  only  about  50–100  hectares  (ha)  per 
subproject.  These  are  usually  located  in  the  lowlands  and  far  from  forested  areas  or 
environmentally  critical  areas.  Rehabilitation  works  would  involve  restoration  of  damaged 
existing  irrigation  canals,  structures,  and  drainage  facilities,  and  involve  no  right-of-way 
acquisition.  New  construction  would  include  replacement  of  existing  brush  dams  with  a 
permanent run-of-the-river diversion system with canal conveyance facilities to the irrigable 
area. Right-of-way acquisition for the canal system is expected, with appropriate compensation 
by the Project. To prevent possible conflict from downstream users, if any, water permits will 
have to be secured from the National Water Resources Board as required under Philippine 
regulation. The design of communal irrigation schemes using this type of diversion will adopt the 
standard specifications of the National Irrigation Administration, while those that are proposed 
for small water impounding projects will adopt the standard specifications of the Bureau of Soils 
and Water Management under the Department of Agriculture. These designs will take into 
consideration  the  necessary  drainage  facilities  and  slope  protection  works  along  areas  of 
embankments and steep side slopes. 
 
18.  Proposed potable water supply projects would only involve level 1 using groundwater 
sources and level 2 using natural springs. Site selection and design would consider factors like 
dependable supply of water source, adequate buffer distance from sources of contaminants 
(toilets, septic tanks, garbage areas), and drainage run-off. Proposed sources will be certified 
potable  by  the  Department  of  Health  or  the  local  health  office.  Design  of  spring  boxes, 
distribution reservoirs, and pipelines will adopt the standard specifications of the Department of 
Public Works and Highways and the Local Water Utilities Administration. To avoid possible 
conflict with existing local water districts and other users of the same source, if any, clearances 
and water permits from these institutions will be secured prior to the approval of the proposed 
subproject.  
 
19.  All  other  proposed  rural  infrastructure  like  multipurpose  buildings  and  other  social 
facilities will have very negligible environmental impacts. 
 
2.  Environmental Issues Related to Construction 
20.  Common nuisances caused by construction activities would include dust pollution, noise, 
obnoxious gases, traffic, or obstruction to public access. While all are temporary in nature, they 
can  be  minimized  through  water  spraying  of  transport  routes,  using  equipment  in  good 
operational condition, and careful planning and scheduling of work. Destabilization of slopes

Appendix 8  57
and soil erosion may also occur along excavation sites, and these could be mitigated by the 
appropriate shoring of areas expected to erode. Another possible impact, the illegal sourcing of 
construction materials, can be avoided through proper coordination with local officials. Possible 
water contamination by oil and grease from heavy equipment repair works can be mitigated by 
providing ring canals and grease traps around equipment pools and fuel depots, respectively. 
Silt traps will be provided, as needed, around construction sites to prevent eroded materials 
from entering water bodies. 
 
21.  Irrigation development would be done mostly within farmlands and far from residential 
areas, causing minimal disturbance to households and potable water supply systems.  
 
22.  The workforce will be provided with safety gear like construction helmets and work boots 
during construction. 
 
3.  Environmental Problems Related to Operation 
23.  Operation and maintenance of completed facilities would be the main responsibility of 
the LGUs through their operation and maintenance committees, irrigation associations, farmers’ 
organizations, and barangay water and sanitation associations. All these organizations will be 
trained on proper operations and maintenance through the capacity-development interventions 
to be provided under the Project. Vegetation control along farm-to-market roads and de-silting 
and  unclogging  of  drainage  facilities  will  be  done  regularly  by  the  LGU  operations  and 
maintenance  committees,  while  inspection  of  pipelines  and  cleaning  of  spring  boxes  and 
distribution reservoirs will be undertaken by the barangay water and sanitation associations. 
The possible increased use of agrochemicals because of crop intensification will be mitigated 
through rigorous training of farmer irrigators on the proper application of inorganic fertilizers and 
pesticides and the introduction of and advocacy for organic farming practices. The farmers will 
be required to develop an integrated pest and crop management program with assistance from 
the Project. The use of agrochemicals will be controlled following the recommended type and 
dosage of the Fertilizer and Pesticide Authority. The irrigation association would also be trained 
on proper irrigation water management and establishment of a system of collecting irrigators’ 
service fees for sustainability. Reforestation of critical watershed areas of irrigation and potable 
water sources will be pursued and initiated by the LGUs with assistance from DENR and full 
involvement of the barangay water and sanitation associations. 
 
E.  Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Plan 
22.  Mitigation  measures  will  be  largely  the  responsibility  of  contractors  during  actual 
construction  procedures,  while  subproject  siting  and  design  will  be  done  by  the  LGUs. 
Operations and maintenance environmental protection measures will be done by the respective 
operations and maintenance committees and organizations, with some assistance from the LGU 
and line agencies. The responsibility for monitoring of compliance with these measures lies with 
DAR project offices at all levels with the full involvement of the LGUs. DAR and LGUs will set up 
a mechanism to ensure that monitoring responsibilities are understood and accountabilities are 
clear. A safeguard specialist will be engaged at the DAR central level to provide technical 
assistance to the designated DAR regional and provincial staff. At the municipal LGU, the 
Municipal Planning and Development Office, the Municipal Social Welfare Development Office, 
the municipal engineer, and the community officer will be designated as the safeguard unit for 
all types of subprojects. Review of subproject sitings and detailed engineering design will be 
done by DAR provincial, regional, and central project offices. Reviews will be conducted in 
accordance with the subproject assessment procedures, guidelines, and templates, as well as

58  Appendix 8 
the  environmental  management  and  monitoring  plan  referred  to  in  the  environmental 
assessment and review procedure (EARP). Ground implementation and compliance with EARP 
requirements will be supervised daily by the LGU’s local project office, with DAR Provincial 
Project  Office  (PPO)  and  the  regional  project  office  conducting  periodic  site  visits.  ADB 
supervision missions will be undertaken to review and assess the overall work progress as well 
as  compliance  with  safeguard  policies.  The  operations  and  maintenance  phase  will  be 
monitored largely by the LGUs at the municipal level with periodic assistance from DAR and 
government line and regulatory agencies.  
 
F.  Public Consultation and Disclosure 
23.  Public consultation and disclosure is a continuing process in project development to 
ensure  compliance  with  the  environmental  and  social  safeguards.  Public  consultation  and 
disclosure of project environment documents were conducted between August–November 2005 
and  September  2007.  Some  feedback  was  received  on  environment  management 
considerations  for  road  construction  and  solar  driers,  and  it  was  incorporated  in  the  IEE. 
Consultations  also  disclosed  and  verified  institutional  arrangements  for  implementing  the 
environmental assessment guidelines contained in the EARP.    
 
G.  Capacity development Activities   
 
24.  The environmental management capacity of the LGUs, DAR regional and provincial 
office  staff,  and  the  ARCs  is  rated  low.  Training  is  essential  for  implementing  the  EARP 
framework (Supplementary Appendix I) developed under the Project to comply with ADB and 
DENR environmental requirements for future subprojects. Training (with group workshops on 
skill building and practical applications) will be conducted on the following: 
 
(i)  Philippine Environment Information System (EIS) system, focused on IEE and 
Environment Management Plan (EMP) preparation; 
(ii)  Philippine  environmental  regulations  and  ADB  environmental  and  social 
safeguards; 
(iii)  Philippine watershed and natural resources management; 
(iv)  requirements  and  procedures  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  subprojects 
(training on EARP; and 
(v)  understanding  the  subproject  design  and  operations  (overview  of  subproject 
descriptions—first part of IEE). 
 
25.    The estimated cost for training is P8.80 million, inclusive of the costs of food and 
venue, training supplies and materials, resource persons, organizing, and facilitation.  
 
26.  Each  training  would  involve  two  representatives  from  each  barangay,  two  from  the 
municipal local government units (LGU) project office (preferably the project engineer and the 
environmental officer), and two from DAR (one from the region and one from the province). The 
cost for live-in training is estimated at P1,200 per person per day, while live-out training is P500 
per person per day.

Appendix 9  59
SECTOR ANALYSIS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  Two–thirds of the population live in rural areas and depend on subsistence agriculture 
for their household income.1 The landless farm workers and small farm cultivators, such as 
those in the agrarian reform communities (ARCs) constitute the core of the poorer sectors of the 
rural economy.  
 
2.  During 2001–2003, the Philippine economy grew at a respectable pace, notwithstanding 
internal and external challenges. Gross domestic product growth steadily moved from 3.0% in 
2001 and 4.7% in 2003 to 6.3% in the first half of 2004. Over the same period, the gross 
national product expanded at an average annual rate of 4.5%, which was on track with the 
targets set forth in the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan (MTPDP).2   
 
3.  The agriculture sector registered a steady growth at an average of 3.8% during the 
period  2001–2003  and  further  improved  to  6.3%  in  the  first  half  of  2004.  However,  the 
agriculture sector outputs and improved farm incomes achieved did not translate into significant 
sector-wide rural gains over the 3-year period.  
 
B.  National Policies and Plans  
 
4.  Comprehensive  Agrarian  Reform  Program.  In  1988,  the  pervading  problem  of 
landlessness and unequal land distribution prompted the Government of the Philippines to 
legislate and implement the Comprehensive Agrarian Reform Program (CARP). The primary 
objectives  of  CARP  are  the  improvement  of  equity  and  the  increase  in  productivity  and 
economic growth in the rural areas.  
 
5.  The current 10-point agenda of the current administration focuses on strategic measures 
and priority programs that will spur economic growth, resulting in poverty reduction. Among the 
key measures to be pursued is the creation of 10 million jobs through the development of 2 
million hectares (ha) of productive agribusiness lands and the provision of assistance to 3 
million entrepreneurs.  
 
6.  In line with the 10-point agenda, DAR is pursuing the implementation of land tenure 
improvement and essential support services in ARCs to transform  these communities into 
productive growth areas and to optimize the utilization of agrarian reforms lands for profitable 
agribusiness ventures.   
 
7.  Building on Lessons Learned.  The development framework for the Agrarian Reform 
Communities Project (ARCP) II is premised on a clear understanding of the causes of rural 
poverty in the ARCs. The success and challenges of ARCP led to a greater focus on clarity 
regarding titles, as well as a stronger market orientation for investments.   
 
8.  Strategic  Approach.  The  proposed  ARCP  II  aligns  strongly  with  the  goals  and 
strategies of ADB and the poverty partnership agreement3 between the Government and ADB 
that was formalized on 10 October 2001. Furthermore, the partnership agreement explicitly 
                                                 
1  Reyes, Celia M. 2001. Impact of Agrarian Reform on Poverty: CARP Impact Assessment Studies 7. Manila: DAR. 
2  National Economic Development Authority. 2004. Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan, 2004–2010. Manila: 
National Economic Development Authority. 
3  ADB. 2001. Philippine Poverty Partnership Agreement. Manila

60  Appendix 9 
states as a key strategy acceleration of agrarian reform by fast-tracking land acquisition and 
distribution, and by institutionalizing and rationalizing delivery of support services to all ARBs. 
   
G.  Development Opportunities and Constraints 
9.  Agriculture Potential. A major factor constraining the realization of the development 
potential  of  the  agricultural  sector  is  inadequate  allocation  of  fiscal  resources  to  irrigation 
development and farm-to-market roads, thus limiting farm productivity. The national government 
is making a major shift of infrastructure priorities to the rural areas. 
 
10.  Productivity  Increases.  Agriculture  development  has  achieved  successful  poverty 
reduction in previous and current projects. The ARCP design for support to agriculture and 
enterprise development is still appropriate and should be continued and enhanced under ARCP 
II.   
 
11.  Vast Scope.  As of June 2006, there are more than 4 million ARBs on 6.7 million ha 
across the Philippines, representing 73% of the total CARP target of 9.1 million ha. DAR has 
organized almost 1,800 ARCs, including those in the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao, 
covering about 1.7 million ha. Collectively, the ARCs cover 42% of the total land transfer 
achieved to date. Significant effort is still required to move ARBs from subsistence production 
into sustainable commercial-oriented production that will ultimately lead to the ARC households 
moving permanently above the poverty line.   
 
12.  Enhancement  of  Connectivity  of  the  ARCs.  DAR  has  been  seeking  innovative 
approaches by which to achieve stronger and longer-term economic impact in the ARCs as well 
as  in  non-ARC  barangays  with  a  considerable  number  of  ARBs.  To  enhance  the  ARC 
development strategy, DAR is now promoting an approach that goes beyond ARC boundaries, 
such as ARC connectivity.   
 
13.  Land  Tenure  Improvements.  A  number  of  challenges  in  the  land  acquisition  and 
transfer process still need to be addressed, including the subdivision of collective certificates of 
land ownership awards, amortization of land, resolution of disputes among beneficiaries, and 
accurate technical descriptions of lands, among others.  
D.  Conclusion 
   
14.  The Project will address the key concerns of the rural sector and aim to break the vicious 
cycle of debt, low incomes, and lack of access. Through a social inclusion approach, it will bring 
in the vulnerable and formerly neglected segments in target areas to gain a voice in decision-
making and an opportunity to participate in improving the quality of their lives.

development  Community–driven  development  ––  broadly  defined  —  is  an 
approach  that  gives  control  over  planning  decisions  and 
investment  resources  to  community  groups  and  local 
governments. It facilitates inclusion of the poor in the community. 
It can ensure the participation of the different segments of the 
community  in  monitoring  project  activities,  procurement,  and 
implementation, as well as encourages transparency.
